Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Absinthe is traditionally bottled at a high level of alcohol by volume, but it is normally diluted with water before being is an anise-flavored spirit derived from several plants, including the flowers and leaves of grand wormwood, together with green anise, sweet fennel, and other medicinal and culinary herbs. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Absinthe is traditionally bottled at a high level of alcohol by volume, but it is normally diluted with water before being consumed.","categoryType":"spirit","refs":[],"parents":[],"slug":"absinthe","type":"category","quantity":{"amount":1,"unit":"dash"}}],"preparation":"shaken","served_on":"crushed ice","glassware":"tiki","instructions":["Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.","Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.","Strain into a tiki mug or rocks glass filled with crushed ice."],"attributions":[{"source":"Jessica Manzey","relation":"recipe author"}],"refs":[{"type":"book","title":"Easy Tiki","page":146}],"slug":"jah-rule","source":{"$schema":"../../../../schemas/book.schema.json","name":"Easy Tiki","link":"https://www.penguinrandomhouse.ca/books/606720/easy-tiki-by-chloe-frechette-and-editors-of-punch/9781984856753","description":"Tiki is the dream of escape, a tropical vacation complete with warm ocean water, island music, and beachside dinners. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. George Absinthe Verte","type":"spirit","categories":[{"$schema":"../../schemas/category.schema.json","name":"Absinthe","description":"Absinthe is an anise-flavored spirit derived from several plants, including the flowers and leaves of grand wormwood, together with green anise, sweet fennel, and other medicinal and culinary herbs. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Absinthe is traditionally bottled at a high level of alcohol by volume, but it is normally diluted with water before being While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Absinthe is traditionally bottled at a high level of alcohol by volume, but it is normally diluted with water before being consumed.","categoryType":"spirit","refs":[],"parents":[],"slug":"absinthe","type":"category"}],"slug":"vieux-pontarlier-absinthe","refs":[],"ingredients":[],"quantity":{"amount":1,"unit":"tsp"}},{"$schema":"../../../schemas/ingredient.schema.json","name":"Barbancourt White","type":"spirit","categories":[{"$schema":"../../schemas/category.schema.json","name":"Rhum Agricole Blanc","description":"Rhum agricole is the French term for sugarcane juice rum, a style of rum originally distilled in the French Caribbean islands from freshly squeezed sugarcane juice rather than molasses. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Absinthe is traditionally bottled at a high level of alcohol by volume, but it is normally diluted with water before being Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners. Absinthe is traditionally bottled at a high level of alcohol by volume, but it is normally diluted with water before being consumed.","categoryType":"spirit","refs":[],"parents":[],"slug":"absinthe","type":"category"}],"slug":"herbsaint","refs":[],"ingredients":[]},{"name":"Angostura bitters","type":"bitter","quantity":{"amount":1,"unit":"part"},"$schema":"../../../schemas/ingredient.schema.json","categories":[{"$schema":"../../schemas/category.schema.json","name":"Aromatic Bitters","categoryType":"bitter","refs":[],"parents":[],"slug":"aromatic-bitters","type":"category"}],"slug":"angostura-bitters","refs":[],"ingredients":[]}],"slug":"herbstura","categories":[],"refs":[],"quantity":{"amount":2,"unit":"dash"}}],"refs":[{"type":"book","page":68,"title":"smugglers-cove"}],"attributions":[{"relation":"bar","source":"Smuggler's Cove","location":"San Francisco, CA"}],"slug":"tiki-bowl","chapter":"02_The Golden Era","source":{"$schema":"../../../../schemas/book.schema.json","name":"Smuggler's Cove","link":"https://www.smugglerscovesf.com/book","description":"Cast aside your cares and worries. Historically described as a highly alcoholic spirit, it is 45–74% ABV (alcohol by volume). Absinthe traditionally has a natural green color but may also be colorless. It is commonly referred to in historical literature as la fée verte 'the green fairy'. While sometimes casually referred to as a liqueur, absinthe unlike pastis is not usually bottled with sugar or sweeteners.
